issues.description: The solution repository implements animal classes with a "Space" prefix (SpaceSeal, SpacePig, SpaceGoat) instead of the animal class names required by the problem statement and referenced in the template (Seal, Pig, Goat). The problem statement, UML and task descriptions explicitly name Seal, Pig and Goat and the template Main.java instantiates Seal, Pig and Goat. Because the solution uses different class/type names, students looking at the solution will be confused about which classes to create, and automated tests or example code that expect Seal/Pig/Goat will not match the solution classes. Additionally, the solution leaves the expected Seal.java, Pig.java and Goat.java files effectively unimplemented while providing the Space* variants, creating a structural mismatch between the problem spec/template and the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's concrete animal classes match the names and types described in the problem statement (Seal, Pig, Goat). Either rename SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat to Seal/Pig/Goat and update their constructors/strings accordingly, or add Seal/Pig/Goat wrapper classes that extend or delegate to the Space* classes so that code/tests referencing Seal/Pig/Goat compile and produce the expected strings. Ensure messageOnMilk() and messageOnRide() produce strings consistent with the intended animal type names (e.g., "Seal Clarabelle is milked" or using getClass().getSimpleName() so the class name matches the expected output). This will align the solution repository with the problem specification and the template usage.

issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect animal classes named Seal, Pig, and Goat (these names appear in the UML and in the template Main.java where instances are created). The provided solution, however, implements the corresponding behavior in classes named SpaceSeal, SpacePig, and SpaceGoat. This naming mismatch (Seal/Pig/Goat vs. SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat) breaks the direct mapping students are instructed to implement and will confuse students who look for Seal/Pig/Goat implementations in the solution. It also affects expected runtime strings that include the class name (e.g., messageOnMilk/messageOnRide may produce "SpacePig ..." instead of the expected "Pig ...").
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class names consistent across artifacts. Either (A) rename the solution classes to Seal, Pig, and Goat (or add Seal/Pig/Goat wrappers that delegate to the Space* implementations) so the solution matches the UML and template, and ensure messageOnMilk()/messageOnRide() use the intended class names; or (B) update the problem statement and template to consistently use the SpaceSeal/SpacePig/SpaceGoat names and document that the animal type includes the 'Space' prefix. Option A (renaming solution classes to Seal/Pig/Goat) is recommended to minimize student confusion.
